name: Zac Chaffin
description: Red and White streaked. Large, semidouble. Vigorous, spreading, upright growth. M-L. (U.S. 1994 - Dr. O. Lewis, Picayune, MS).

name: Zambo
description: Crimson veined Darker Red. Medium, formal double. M. (Aus. 1874 - Dr. R. C. Merrillees, Vic.).

name: Zaomudan
description: See 'Early Peony'.

name: Zaotaohong
description: See 'Early Crimson'.

name: Zebulon
description: Soft White petals very lightly tinted with soft Amaranth, chopped and streaked with Vermillion with Yellow anthers and Yellow filaments. Large, semidouble to full peony. Average, upright and spreading growth. M. (U.S. 2014 - Waters, England, imported from Nantes, France).

name: Zelda Fitzgerald
description: Blush Pink with darker ruffled border and stamen boss a blend of Pinks with Dark Yellow anthers. Medium, anemone form. Average, compact, upright growth. M. (U.S. 2008 - Bobby Green, Green Nurseries, Fairhope, AL).

name: Zell Boyce
description: Orchid Pink. Large to very large, semidouble to loose peony form. M-L. (Reticulata seedling). (U.S. 1975 - Gentry).

name: Zelma Crockett
description: Red and Pink. Medium to large, anemone form. Average, open, upright growth. M. (U.S. 2003 - Jack Midgett, Virginia Beach, VA).

name: Zenobia
description: Oriental Red. Very large, peony form with clusters of Gold stamens between petal layers and rabbit ears in center. Average, open, upright growth. E-L. (U.S. 1994 - Z. Kendig, Lutherville, MD).

name: Zephyr
description: Fire Red. Large, peony form with Golden stamens interspersed with curving petaloids. (U.S. 1965 - Wilson).

name: Zhangjia Cha
description: See 'Chang's Temple'.

name: Zhanqun Lady
description: ('Da Qio' - Chinese Name). Very Light Pink with slightly Deeper Pink on petal outer rim. Large to very large, rose form double to formal double with upstanding, separated, and mainly fluted petals. Vigorous growth. L. I(Reticulata hybrid 'Suzanne Withers' × 'Nitidissima hybrid 'Honeymoon') × Japonica 'Kona']. (U.S. 2012 - John Wang, Orinda, CA).

name: Zhusha Zipao
description: See 'Vermillion Purple Gown'.

name: Zi Pian
description: See 'Purple Petal'.

name: Zilpha Slauenwhite
description: Rose Pink. Small, semidouble with upright petals intermingled with stamens. Average, upright growth. M. (U.S. 1965 - Mrs. E. Cain, Mullins, SC).

name: Zina Marie
description: Pale Pink center deepening to Rich Pink at edges. Medium, formal double. Slow, bushy growth. M. (U.S. 1980 - Feathers).

name: Zing
description: Rose Red. Miniature, formal double. Vigorous, bushy upright growth. M. (U.S. 1973 - McCaskill).

name: Zipao
description: See 'Purple Gown'. ( )

name: Zoe Elizabeth
description: Blood Red. Medium, formal double. Upright growth. M-L. (Aus. 1985 - R. Keightley, Wattlepark, S. Aus.).

name: Zorina
description: Deep Red. Large, formal double to rose form double. L. (U.S. 1969 - Armstrong).

name: Zuijiaohong
description: See 'Intoxicatingly Beautiful Red'. Hybrids With Other Than Reticulata Parentage (Non- Reticulata hybrids) Hybrids with Reticulata parentage previously have been listed in the section entitled 'Species Reticulata and Hybrids with Reticulata Parentage. The following are cultivars of hybrids with parentage other than Reticulata. Many of these hybrids are Saluenensis × Japonica which generally are known as Williamsii Hybrids.

name: Zuiko-Nishiki
description: White splashed Red. Medium, single. See Higo. SPECIES RETICULATA AND HYBRIDS WITH RETICULATA PARENTAGE The predominant opinion is that Reticulata is not a distinct species, but is a hybrid of other species, probably largely Pitardii (which also is believed to be a hybrid) fractionally combined with Japonica. The Yunnan Reticulatas, which were imported into the United States from China in 1948 by Ralph S. Peer of Hollywood, California and Descanso Gardens of La Canada, generally have been listed as Reticulata and their seedlings listed as Reticulata Hybrids. It is the opinion of many that such cultivars represent garden forms of Reticulata, some Pitardii Variety Yunnanica, and some hybrid crosses of both. Many such cultivars are over three hundred years old. Therefore, it is believed advisable to list Reticulatas and Hybrids with Reticulata Parentage in this same section. Cultivars imported directly to the United States from China during the 40's, 50's, 60's and 80's have been marked with an asterisk (*).
